text: when I was young and in a band that's
starting out in like punk rock and indie
rock bands we were trying to stick it to
the man we wanted to stick it to the oil
companies we wanted to stick it to the
walmarts and stuff like that here with
file sharing of music and songs you're
doing exactly the opposite you're paying
for the 4G connection to AT&T or Verizon
you're paying the broadband providers
you're paying the hardware makers but
you're not paying the hippie freak
musician
I teach about 230 kids at the University
of Georgia who are aspiring musicians
and stuff like that I teach these
students about the economics of the
music business and one of the first
things I have to get through to them is
sharing is not carrying
while sharing is a bad thing and they're
completely hostile to me when I first
confront them with this so I spend quite
a bit of time pointing out the
contradictions and the a morality and
their unethical behavior
we still need to do something here and
everybody started talking like well
let's form a union let's form a lobbying
group let's form some sort of collective
and I don't remember who it was but one
person said let's just start a blog and
so we just started writing about this
stuff because nobody was writing about
these issues of piracy streaming web
casting and the rate that were being
paid and will be paid in future from the
artists perspective so there was a lot
of trepidation as we started this blog
we didn't know what would happen and as
a result there was a background but I'm
the kind of person that I kind of don't
care
a lot of my students didn't get this
idea that you should be able to control
your own or until the Instagram fiasco
and they suddenly realize that wait a
minute a big commercial company gets to
do whatever they want with my photos
that's not right then suddenly a light
bulb goes on over these kids heads and
they say wait a minute I get it there
are a lot of people out there who
consciously make a disingenuous argument
about what I'm doing they want to say
I'm pining for a lost past this isn't
about my money I've made ninety-eight
percent of the money that I'll ever make
in the music business this is about a
fair music business for my son's bands
and for those students that I'm teaching
for their bands a future
you
